userreviews.userReview: A little to "out there" for me. I didn't find it believable - because I do not believe in reincarnation - so it made it far fetched to me. The personality studies were good and character development was interesting.

I LOVED, LOVED, LOVED this book. It was such a refreshingly different story line. The truisms were plentiful, I highlighted several of them. I empathized with several of the characters, and hated to see the book end.

It reminds me uncomfortably of "The Five People You Meet in Heaven," one of my most despised reads of all time, yet it wasn't as horrible. When I compare it with "Say Goodbye for Now," I get very sad. Weird obsession with justice and moving on = misguided. Especially given the assertion that this ephemera ceases to matter once we die and are subsumed into oneness with time and the universe. Additionally, what a boring and dickless man was this Walter. Yawn. Also, why wasn't Michael more assertive about pursuing his own life and desires?? Finally, it was too long, continuing looong after Walter had completed his self-assigned mission. If there had been a plot twist at the end, it might have been worth it. Alas, no such luck. Still, this writer is clearly a true talent, as you can see when she has a real story to tell. I would give a different tome of hers a try, and I will. My new rule for myself is _never_ to read anything having the slightest reference to WWII- I AM OVER IT.

My rating is really based on the first 80% of the book, which was interesting and unique. It had the same quality of the author's other novels but with a really different spin. As usual, there was depth and interesting backstories, sorrow, and triumph. But the really interesting thing was having the story of Walter told by Walter after his death. However, I actually was a little over the ending; I thought the beginning was messy and real- the ending didn't need to be so tidy. Still beautiful.

Quite different from most of the rest and not quite as good. Part of the problem was probably the insane hassle I had trying to get Hoopla to work which made for a very fragmented listening experience.
This novel is recommended for its unique way of addressing death. If you have a fear of death then this novel is a must read.
Great readIf you like unusual books, this one is for you. Life after death , or not? This is a heartwarming look at second chances.
Pure pleasureSo glad Catherine wrote this book. Gave m such a warm feeling seeing these characters grow. Thank you, Ms. Ryan
A very quirky book, but I liked it a lot.
DifferentInteresting concept and well written. An enjoyable, easy read bouncing around from character to character to advance plot and storyline.
Although I don't believe in reincarnation, I enjoyed this book. It's a telling of how we never really forget....
Interesting storyInteresting story. Walter started off as kooky but became ever more reasonable as the story continued. Loved how completely open Michael was to the ed vents.

Every life matters even if it is the enemy.The beginning of this book is a little rocky. I am glad this wasn't the first book I read by this author. I may not have stuck with the confusing parts. I'm glad I read on. Walter has to kiss his girl good night. He has to kiss her in a way that will last through WWII, if he comes home or forever if he doesn't. Usually, when the hero dies, the story is over. This one is just beginning.We're headed back to Henderson field, relieved of the WORST duty known to man. I never really knew how awful a job was until that magic moment when I got to stop. Death doesn't hurt. Sometimes the events leading up to it can be painful, but the dying is always easy. There's a special kind of freedom to that moment. Things don't wait for a person to believe in them, they happen. Walter found a real sense of safety in reincarnation. Nothing ends but everything changes. In those changes something is gained but something very important is lost. It's so much bigger than words. I have to squeeze it down small to fit into words. Then it's like a shadow of what I know I felt. Now the most tedious and uneventful day I ever spent feels like a gift.

Very Interesting BookNot sure I believe in the premise of this book, but found this book very interesting nevertheless. Wasn't sure I liked Michael at first, wondered why Walter picked him, but grew to like him. Liked Walter a lot, bad things happen to good people. Mary Ann got dealt a bad hand, but not sure marrying Walter was a good choice, especially when she explained why Walter and her never had a family! Andrew still mulling him over in my mind, although he paid for his choices all his life. Book really drew me in, again interesting premise. This is the 2nd book I read by this author! I will continue to read her books. Great read

I have been reading a lot by this author lately. "Pay It Forward" deserved every positive review it got. "Electric God" was also well-written, a good story, honest characters. I have enjoyed most of the books I've read by Catherine Ryan Hyde - but this one was not my favorite. The premise is a little strange, but even if you can suspend belief long enough to follow along, it still doesn't hold together. There are 4 main characters in the book, and while Mary Ann, Andrew and Walter are wonderfully crafted, Michael just doesn't get his due. He is more of a suggestion than a character, yet all of the action circles around him.

Having finished this book I'm still doubting if I read something good and just haven't noticed or it was really so stupid as I feel. I give these 2 stars only for some parts with the memories - it's really enjoyable and well-written. But the whole plot is absolute craziness - like "Pearl Harbour" movie scenario is transferred into trash movie. Reincarnation, spiritual tables, love between 21-years old boy and 60+ woman... Doesn't this writer feel by herself that something is wrong with the story? THis book has high ratings so you always have chance to make your own opinion. But for me it was waste of time.

WWII casualty reincarnates into a current 21 yr old stoner to resolve issues of the past with this best friend, girlfriend, brother, and mom. As usual, Ms. Hyde's characters are so vivid, they dance off the page and you miss them all when you finish the book. Excellent story; don't think it's a paranormal juju fest. It is so much more than that. Another brilliant study in human relationships.

This book earns a three star rating because it is Catherine Ryan Hyde and her writing alone deserves such. The story is about reincarnation, but even if I can let my mind go there and believe the premise, how it plays out is just too unbelievable. I do not believe that the main characters would be affected or act the way that they did. Sorry, but a love story between a 60 yr. old and 21 yr. old just stretches the imagination a bit too far.

ReincarnationAn interesting but strange book. I don't believe in reincarnation and after reading this book I doing think this author does either. I think this book was about enjoying the time you have on earth and to let go of grudges. That's basically what I took away from reading this novel.

an intriguing look into the mystery of reincarnation. A young man begins to have nightmares about a war he was never in, and then is asked by Walter, a long dead soldier to do him a favor. This leads the young man to discover a life he never knew about, and a person who becomes essential to his own life, causing Walter's life to intertwine with his own.

While I adore Catherine Ryan Hyde, this book didn't quite work for me. I characters never came alive like I wanted them to, and though it was interesting, with past lives intermingling with modern day woes, the whole thing failed to reach through to touch me in a meaningful way.

I enjoyed this book and contemplated a rating of 4, but there was just something missing. I just couldn't get really into the reincarnation thing, and I didn't understand some of the points the author was trying to drive home.
Life and DeathAnd more life. The story begins with Walter dying too young in WWII. Then he has to learn how to live and to teach the people he loves how to live and die. Great story.

Just another reason why I love her books.I couldn't put this book down. I knew by the title it was going to captivate me and require my undivided attention. Indeed it did! What I wouldn't give to find my brother reincarnated like Robbie found his!
Reincarnation?The more you read this book the more intrigued you become. It handles the subject in a very easy way. Casual and just possibly understandable? Love this author. Recommend.

This book will keep you awakeIt jumped all over the characters back to back and at first it drove me crazy but I got so I loved it. It was easy to put down and come back to. A great Story, as artfully written leaning towards reincarnation and how to die with a clear conscience

WonderfulThis was such an amazing book. Catherine is an awesome author. This book has made me wonder about what happens when we die. It brought sad and happy tears to my eyes. I still have tears as I write this review. Very moving. I highly recommend it.
I don't believe in reincarnation, but it made a wonderful story in "Walter's Purple Heart". Another "must read" from Catherine Ryan Hyde.
I didn't care for this book, didn't really like any of the characters.
I would actually give this book 3 1/2 stars. I really liked the idea of the book. I think she could have done a bit more with the story though. But still an enjoyable story.

description: From the author of PAY IT FORWARD and ELECTRIC GOD, a stunningly original and romantic story of a dead World War II soldier who reaches through time to touch the people he loved most. Michael Steeb is young and more than a bit lost, living a ramshackle life in California with few material possessions, little direction and no real goals, until Walter arrives. As the dead man's past becomes entwined with Michaels' own memories, this spiritual connection moves Michael's mind and transforms his identity and direction. Walter gives Michael a mission: to find Walter's old war buddy, Andrew, and tell him the truth about Walter's Purple Heart. Finally locating the sixty-year old man, Michael travels to Albuquerque to relay Walter's message. He arrives to a surprise: not only does he find Andrew, he also finds Mary Ann, the girl left behind after Walter was killed by a Japanese soldier. It seems that Andrew stepped in and took care of everything when Walter didn't come home, including his best friend's fiancee. While Andrew considers Michael to be deluded, or a conman, or both, Mary Ann falls in love with the young man as a way of reenacting her love affair with Walter. Together, the two explore the past and search for the future, despite the realities that may forever change their lives.
title: Walter's Purple Heart
